Fig. 1 (a) Schematic illustration of synthetic routes of Mn-doped CoP/NF. (b) TEM images of Mn10-doped CoP. (c) side view Mn−Co−P (101) with two Mn atoms replacing the subsurface Co atoms. Purple, blue, and light gray balls represent Mn, Co, and P atoms, respectively. (d)Free-energy diagram for HER on pristine CoP (101), Pt, and Mn−Co−P (101) with 8.3 % Mn doping. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) XPS spectra of Mn-CoP and R-Mn-CoP catalysts for P elements. (b) Schematic illustration of the fabrication process of manganese Mn-doped NiP2 nanosheets on carbon cloth. (c) N2 adsorption-desorption of FeP and Mn-FeP. (d) HER polarization curves. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) The preparation procedure of Fe-CoP UNSs/NF. (b) SEM image of Fe-CoP UNSs/NF. (c) SEM image of porous Co0.68Fe0.32P polyhedrons. Inset is the corresponding magnified image. (d) HER analyses of Co0.44Fe0.56P, Co0.68Fe0.32P, CoP, FeP, and Pt/C electrocatalysts in nitrogen-saturated 1.0 M aq. KOH solution, Overpotentials at the rate 10 mA·cm−2. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) XANES spectra at the Co K-edge. (b) The ΔGH*value of Co2P, Mn-Co2P, Fe-Co2P. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) SEM images of Fe1V3-PC/NF. (b) HER polarization curve (c) Gibbs free energies of absorbed hydrogen atom (ΔGH*) for HER. Inset: Volcano plot depicting HER overpotentials as a functional of ΔGH*. (d) HER polarization curves for NF@Ni/C, NF@Ni2P/C, NF@Fe2-Ni/C, NF@Fe2-Ni2P/C, NF@Pt/C, NF. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) Schematic Illustration and structural characterization. (b) Comparison of overpotential at j = 10 mA·cm−2 of different catalysts in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M KOH. (c) TEM images of Ni-CoP-5 %. (d) DFT calculations of the reaction coordination during HER with Ni-CoP. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a) LSV curves of the Pt/C and Co-Ni-P catalysts for HER in 1 M KOH. (b) The corresponding Tafel plots of HER polarization curves. (c) Schematic illustration of the preparation of the hierarchical Ni-FeP/TiN/CC electrocatalyst. (d) Ni-FeP/TiN/CC with symbol A showing the amorphous TiN surface. (e) FTIR spectra of MIL-88A, NM-1, NM-2, and NM-3. (f) LSV curves of the FeP/C, NFP/C-1, NFP/C-2, NFP/C-3. Fig 7 Fig. 8 (a) Schematic illustration of the synthesis of Co-Fe-P nanotubes. (b) TEM images of CoFeOx nanostructure. (c) LSV curves of the rGO, 10 wt% Pt/C, NiCoP, and NiCoP/rGO hybrids in 0.5 M H2SO4. (d) pH-dependent polarization curves of the NiCoP/rGO catalyst at a scan rate of 5 mV·s−1. Fig 8 Fig. 9 (a) Schematic illustration of the preparation of paintbrush-like Co-Cu3P/CF. (b) SEM image of Co-Cu3P/CF. (c) Polarization curves for FeP/Ti, Co-FeP/Ti, Ni-FeP/Ti, and Mn-FeP/Ti in 0.5 M H2SO4. (d) Normalized Fe K-edge XANES spectra. Fig 9 Fig. 10 (a) Schematic of the synthesis of CoMo(Al)-P/NF through the phosphorization of CoMoAl-LTH/NF. (b) Polarization curves Alkaline that HER activity of nickel foam (NF), CoP/NF, CoMo-P/NF, CoMo(Al)-P/NF, Pt/C-20/NF, and Pt/C-40/NF electrocatalysts. (c) SEM images for Al-CoP/CC. With the soaring price of traditional energy and environmental pollution, it is important to find reliable and environmentally friendly clean energy. Transition Metal Phosphides (TMPs) have been shown to perform well compared to other non-precious metal catalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalysts. The modifications of transition metal phosphides can obtain better catalytic performance. Among that, metal doping has become a commonly used method for modifying transition metal phosphides, because it can control the amount of doping and the synthesis method is simple. Metal atom doping greatly changes the intrinsic properties of transition metal phosphides, such as adding Electrochemical Active Surface Area (ESCA), adjusting the electronic structure, etc. Transition metal phosphides can also improve catalytic activity by constructing composite materials such as NiCoP/rGO. Polymetallic doping can also improve the catalytic performance of TMPs, such as CoMo(Al)-P. Through the synergy between polymetals, the catalytic activity of the catalyst is greatly improved. Therefore, it can be developed in the direction of high-entropy alloys to produce catalysts with excellent performance. And TMPs also have good catalytic activity in seawater, such as Fe–Co2P BNRs. A series of modification methods such as metal doping will greatly tap the hydrogen evolution reaction potential of transition metal phosphides, and are expected to be applied in industry. Graphical abstract As we all know, electrolysis of water is two and a half reactions of hydrogen evolution and oxygen evolution. Almost all transition metal phosphides electrocatalysts are highly active oxygen evolution reaction performance under basic conditions. Therefore, it is very important to develop the hydrogen evolution reaction catalytic activity of transition metal phosphides catalysts. Doping modification of transition metal phosphides is one of the commonly used methods. That series of materials from doping metal atoms can own good hydrogen evolution reaction catalytic activity under different pH values. In addition, doping metal atoms in transition metal phosphides can promote electron transfer, thereby greatly reducing ΔGH* and promoting hydrogen evolution reaction. Meanwhile, it can also provide more active sites and expand the specific surface area of transition metal phosphides. It can be seen that doped metal atoms are conducive to the application of transition metal phosphides in the electrolyzed water industry. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Modification Doping Metal atoms TMPs HER Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction At a time when traditional fossil fuels are polluting and depleted, it is important to find a clean and renewable source of energy. The hydrogen can be made through electrolysis of water, can replace the current serious pollution and non-renewable traditional energy. Electrolytic water has a long history of development, with over 200 years to date. The development process is shown in Table 1 . But the efficiency of electrolytic water is not yet high at present. To make HER efficient, it is necessary to electrolyze water with a low overpotential [1,2]. So we generally use catalysts to reduce the passing point [3]. Platinum is the most efficient in hydrogen evolution reactions, which cannot be widely used caused by its low reserves and high price [4,5]. While nickel and its alloys are potential HER materials in alkaline media, they undergo extensive inactivation during alkaline water electrolysis. Therefore, it is imperative to create a catalyst that is minimal in cost, highly active, and stable. Based on this reason, Co, Ni, Fe, Mo, W, Cu and other earth-rich transition metals and their alloy [6–8], nitrides [9–11], borides [12–14], carbides [15–17], sulfides [18–20], phosphides [21–23] and other derivatives [24–26] have been studied. Among these, transition metal phosphides (TMPs) have been extensively studied by researchers. TMPs have a special catalytic mechanism similar to that of hydrogenases [27]. And P atoms can increase the spacing between metal atoms, weaken the interaction between metal atoms, thereby greatly improving conductivity [28]. In addition, phosphating the metal alloy effectively inhibits the dissolution of the metal, thereby improving the stability and corrosiveness of the catalyst [29,30]. In summary, TMPs have abundant content, special structure, excellent catalytic activity and stable properties [31,32], which has attracted widespread attention in the field of electrocatalysis among the many catalysts. These advantages make transition metal phosphides become a promising hydrolysis material. However, the catalytic effect of pure TMPs is still not very ideal. Therefore, many researchers modify it to improve the catalytic performance of TMPs. Element doping are commonly used modification methods. Elemental doping includes metal atom doping, non-metal atom doping, and metal/non-metal atomic co-doping. Among that, metal doping control the amount of doping and the synthesis method is simple. Metal atom doping greatly changes the intrinsic properties of transition metal phosphides, such as adding Electrochemical Active Surface Area (ESCA), adjusting the electronic structure, etc. Therefore, TMPs have important applications in the field of electrocatalytic hydrolysis. 2 Hydrogen evolution reaction mechanism Before discussing the mechanism of hydrogen evolution reactions, it is important to understand the Sabatier principle. The Sabatier principle provides the basis for the principle of activity between catalysts [33]. HER catalysts with good catalytic performance not only possess strong enough adsorption capacity for key reaction intermediates, but also occur desorption when they are weak enough. This will leave space for the product to adsorb another intermediate and maintain the HER [34]. Therefore, it often presents a volcanic curve in the relationship between heat of adsorption and enthalpy of intermediate formation and catalytic rate. However, the volcanic curve does not explain the higher catalytic activity observed at acid solution with low pH [35,36]. In acidic and alkaline solutions, the HER reaction mechanism is different. For example, in acidic media, hydrated hydrogen ions are proton donors, while in alkaline media water becomes proton donors, as shown below: (1) Acidic media: 2H3O+2e− ⇌ H2 (2) Alkaline media: 2H2O+2e− ⇌ H2+2OH− The hydrogen evolution reaction mechanism in different electrolyte solutions is as followed: In acidic media: (3) Volmer H++e−+*→H*+H2O (4) Heyrovsky H++e−+H*→H2+H2O (5) Tafel H*+H*→H2 In alkaline media: (6) Volmer H2O+e−+*→H*+OH− (7) Heyrovsky H2O+e-+H*→H*+OH− (8) Tafel H*+H*→H2 In alkaline media, the activity of HER is about 2-3 grades below than that in acidic media [37]. At the initial potential, HER is more difficult to occur under alkaline electrolyte compared in the acidic electrolyte [38], because the proton hydrogen used in the HER from alkaline medium is obtained by splitting water molecules with additional energy, which affects the overall reaction rate of HER [39,40]. In actual production, no electrolyzer can achieve 100 % Faraday efficiency due to various obstacles with thermodynamic and kinetic. Whether in acidic or alkaline media, the minimum voltage of water electrolysis is 1.23 V. However, the electrolysis of water can hardly be carried out at the theoretical decomposition voltage of 1.23 V, and the excess voltage is called with the over-point position. The overpotential (η) is mainly used to overcome the intrinsic activation barrier present on the anode (ηa) and cathode (ηc), as well as some other resistors (ηother) such as solution resistance and contact resistance. So electrolyzed water can be reflected by the following chemical equation: Eop = 1.23 V + ηa + ηc + ηother It can be seen from this formula that reducing the overpotential is the central problem to make water electrolysis energy-efficient. ηother can be decreased by using optimizing the plan of the electrolyzer, while ηa and ηc must be decreased by way of exceedingly lively oxygen evolution and hydrogen evolution catalysts, respectively. In general, OER is performed by coupling several protons/electrons [41]. In addition, OER is highly sensitive to pH and has very different response kinetics under medium with different pH values [42]. For electrocatalytic OER in acidic solutions, the most broadly used electrocatalysts are the noble metals Ru, Ir and their derivative. Due to poor acid resistance, other materials are not appropriate for acidic OER. Unlike OER in acid solution, almost all TMPs electrocatalysts are highly active OER performance under basic conditions [43]. Therefore, it is very important to synthesize excellent HER catalysts under alkaline conditions. 3 Preparation method of TMPs A long time ago, the synthesis of TMPs mostly required a high temperature and high-pressure environment, which greatly limited the development of TMPs. But with the deepening of the research on TMPs, synthetic methods have sprung up. The metal source and the P source are different, so the synthesis method is different. Metal sources are mainly divided into free metal ions, coordinated metal ions, metals, metal hydroxides, metal oxides, metal phosphoric acid salt and other sources of metals. Phosphorus sources can be divided into organophosphorus (trioctylphosphine (TOP), hexamethylphosphoric triamide (HMPA), tetrabutylphosphonium chloride, organophosphoric acid, etc.) and inorganic phosphorus (PH3 gas, phosphoric acid, phosphate, red phosphorus, black phosphorus, etc.) [44] The synthesis methods under different metal and phosphorus sources are systematically summarized, as shown in Table 2 . TMPs have excellent HER catalytic activity, and their synthesis methods are also diverse. Colloidal synthesis [65–67], hydrothermal [53–55], Chemical vapor deposition [68–70], electrodeposition [71–73] is common synthesis methods. These three common types of methods will be discussed in detail as followed. 3.1 Colloidal synthesis Colloidal synthesis is a method for synthesizing metal phosphate nanoparticles using organic solvents as reaction media. This reaction is usually carried out in inert atmosphere at temperatures ranging from 220°C to 385°C. By controlling the type of precursor, reaction temperature, and molar ratio of M/P, catalysts with different sizes and morphologies can be obtained [74]. For example, Callejas et al. [75] reported the synthesis of low-cost, abnormally active iron phosphide (FeP) nanoparticles. Fe(CO)5 is first mixed with oleylamine and 1-octadecane, and Fe nanoparticles are prepared. The prepared iron nanoparticles are reacted with TOP to convert to FeP. It is reported by Eric J. Popczun that CoP hollow nanoparticles can be prepared by mixing 1-octadecene, oleylamine and trioctylphodphine and then slowly injecting the prepared Co nanoparticle suspension into the reaction mixture [76]. This is a typical structure of TMPs nanoparticles, as TOP is used to chemically convert metal seed particles from the outside in to phosphide. This method can also be applied to the synthesis of other transition metal phosphides [77,78]. Although this method can effectively regulate the morphology of metal phosphides, the presence of toxic organic phosphorus greatly limits its development. 3.2 Hydrothermal Hydrothermal is a common way for synthesizing metallic phosphate. Generally, many different metal salts and phosphorus sources are dissolved in water or solvents, which is saved a necessary time at a reaction temperature below 210°C in a PTFE-lined autoclave, and then TMPs can be successfully acquired. TMPs nanostructures also can be composited by means of solvothermal method using organic solvents as reaction media. For example, nickel foam is put into a mixed solution of anhydrous ethylenediamine and amorphous red P and then placed in an oven for reaction. Finally, it is worth Ni2P-NRs/NF electrodes with good catalytic performance [79]. The method can also be used to synthesize other TMPs [80,81]. The hydrothermal method is simple to operate, but the obtained TMPs are prone to agglomeration. 3.3 Chemical vapor deposition Chemical vapor deposition has the strengths of excessive selectivity, excessive yield and easy procedure, which makes it become a common method for preparing TMPs. Recently, metals and red phosphorus are combined with stoichiometry, sealed in vacuum silicon tubes, and then heated to high temperatures for long periods of time to synthesize TMPs. Later, in order to decrease the reaction temperature and time, the other solid-phase reaction is widely adopted. An instance is the CoMoP catalyst [82], in which a stoichiometric combination of cobalt nitrate, ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate and ammonium phosphate hydrogen phosphate is calcined in air, then treated at H2/Ar. In the synthesis of MoP2 nanoparticles [83], molybdenum oxide and elemental red phosphorus (P) powder are combined, vacuum-sealed in a quartz tube, then are heated and finally acid washed. The solid-phase reaction process is simple, but PH3 highly poisonous gas will be produced for the duration of the reaction, which greatly limits the application of this method. Therefore, it is a very necessary issue how can efficiently collect the poisonous gas when the reaction is completed. 3.4 Electrodeposition Electrodeposition preparation of TMPs is one of the commonly used preparation methods, which can make the ions to be reduced and deposited on the electrode surface to form a coating by the application of electric current or voltage. For example, CoSO4 and NaH2PO2 are dissolved in water as a electrolytic solution, and electrode is linearly scanned 15 times between 0.3 and 1.0V. Finally CoP films can be immediately deposited on copper foil [84]. The obtained CoP films can be used immediately as an electrocatalyst or saved under vacuum at ambient temperature. In the electrodeposition method, the deposition time, voltage, and concentration of ions in the solution will affect the final catalytic activity [85,86]. The electrodeposition method is direct, low power consumption, fast preparation speed, and simple experimental process. 4 The effect of metal doping on TMPs Doping metal or non-metallic atoms can increase the electrocatalytic activity of TMPs. It can promote anion and cation exchange of transition metal phosphides, accelerate charge transfer, and optimize ΔGH* and ΔGH2O for easy adsorption and desorption of HER intermediates. Metals can be incorporated into TMPs, such as Mn, Ni, Co, Fe and so on. Doping metal elements is relatively easy, only a certain amount of dopant needs to be added during the precursor synthesis process, and generally does not require any post-treatment [87]. 4.1 Mn doping Doping Mn atoms is one of the common methods for modifying TMPs. The researchers [88] synthesized the Mn-CoP on NF (Ni Foam), as shown in Fig. 1 a. Due to the different diffusion rates, the phosphine after NaH2PO2 decomposition diffuses to the surface of the precursor, and reacts with Co atoms. Many holes are formed on the surface, and finally form to be the porous cobalt phosphide nanorods, as shown in Fig. 1 b. In the experiment, the result showed that when the manganese doping amount was 10 %, the catalytic activity of CoP was the best. According to the calculation of DFT. An appropriate amount of Mn doping can effectively reduce the overall d-band center of the CoP and provide good H* adsorption and fast reaction kinetics. In general, almost all the best HER catalysts work well only in acidic media, but nearly all the best OER works well in alkaline media, so it is important to find catalysts can work well in all the pH ranges. For example, the manganese-doped CoP (Mn-Co-P) nanosheet array has synthesized by electrodeposition on the Ti network [89], and the synthesized catalyst has good catalytic activity under acidity, alkalinity and neutrality. According to the study [90], the ΔGH* on the surface of the original CoP(101) is -0.14 eV, and when Mn is incorporated into the CoP, the ΔGH* decreases to only -0.11 eV, and the doping of Mn shows that it is easier to replace the Co atoms under the surface, as shown in Fig. 1 c. DFT calculations showed that Mn doping reduces the ΔGH* of the CoP, as shown in Fig. 1 d. Electrochemical experiments also prove that the excellent effect of doping. Mn-CoP only needs 49 mV, 76 mV, 86 mV to reach 10 mA·cm−2 in sulfuric acid solution, potassium hydroxide solution and phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), which is far less than the passing point of CoP. Since the surface material of cobalt phosphate is without difficultly oxidized to phosphate in the air, which is not conducive to electrolysis of water [91]. Therefore, the Mn-CoOOH nanowire is converted into Mn-CoP @ Mn-CoOOH. And the Mn-CoOOH formed not only efficiently prevents the constant oxidation of Mn-CoP, but also during the HER process, efficiently promoting the splitting of water to protons during the electrolysis process [92]. Before in situ oxidation, electroreduction has been firstly performed and labeled as R-Mn-CoP. During the reduction reaction, the valence state of the metallic component changes, producing abundant defects [93] and more coordination-unsaturated spinel structures [94,95]. XPS can confirm the existence of P vacancies in R-Mn-CoP, and the total electron density of the β-CoOOH shell increasing with the increase of P vacancies, thereby increasing the conductivity, as shown in Fig. 2 a. DFT calculation results show that P vacancies can regulate Gibbs function and increase internal activity of the Mn-CoP. Then, Mn-CoP is oxidized to Mn-CoP @ Mn-CoOOH in situ, the catalytic activity is further improved. Manganese incorporation into other TMPs also produces excellent catalytic properties. Mn-Ni NSs precursors are obtained on CC by hydrothermal method, and then phosphorylated Mn-Ni NSs precursors can be formed Mn-NiP2 nanosheets, as shown in Fig. 2 b [96]. According to the XPS consequences, it can be known that after Mn doping, the electron shift from Ni to P becomes smaller [97,98], which promotes the performance of HER. This catalyst has good catalytic activity in all pH ranges, only needing 69 mV, 97 mV, 107 mV to drive 10 mA·cm−2 in sulfuric acid, potassium hydroxide and phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). As we all know, the catalytic activity of iron phosphide HER is very low, much less than that of Pt, but doping Mn with iron phosphide will have a miraculous effect. For example, Mn-doped FeP (Mn-FeP) catalyst is prepared by a simple and controlled composite path [99]. After doping with Mn dopant, the obtained Mn-FeP and FeP both exhibit mesoporous structures, and the mesopores of Mn-FeP decrease by 0.37 compared to FeP, reaching to 11.79 nm, as shown in Fig. 2 c. And the specific surface area of Mn-FeP is much larger than the specific surface area when it is not doped. This shows that Mn doping can offer more active site, thereby facilitating anion and cation exchange during electrocatalysis. Indeed, Mn-FeP catalysts only needs 69, 157, and 173 mV to reach 10 mA·cm−2 in sulfuric acid, PBS, and potassium hydroxide electrolytes solutions, respectively, which is much lower than those of the FeP. When Mn is incorporated into MoP, the electrocatalytic performance is also improved. And the amount of Mn can also affect the electrocatalytic performance. When 0.01, 0.05, 0.1 mol or greater amounts of Mn are incorporated into MoP in acidic media. The results show that 0.05 mol Mn-MoP NSs has the best catalytic activity, only 199 mV can reach 10 mA·cm−2, which is much lower than the doping amount of other Mn, as described in Fig. 2 d. [100] These experimental outcomes confirm the incorporation of Mn into TMPs can improve HER performance. The doping of Mn greatly changed the catalytic activity of TMPs, as shown in Table 3 . After Mn doping, the overpotential was significantly reduced, and the Tafel slope was reduced. And it is easy to see that transition metal phosphides have better catalytic performance in acidic solutions. However, working in acidic solutions for a long time will corrode the catalyst and is not conducive to industrial applications. Therefore, it is very important that the catalyst has good catalytic activity under alkaline conditions. As we all know, durability is an important indicator for evaluating catalysts. As we all know, durability is an important indicator for evaluating catalysts. Chronopotentiometry testing is the most commonly used method for evaluating durability. In general, the test period of chronopotentiometry can be considered to have good stability after 10h. However, the cycle of each test is different [101], so the potential decay rate of each cycle is used as a general indicator of stability evaluation. After a large number of experimental surface Mn-doped catalysts, the decay rate is maintained at a low level after a cycle of cycling. This proves that the doping of Mn can improve the stability of the catalyst. 4.2 Fe doping The incorporation of Fe atoms in TMPs can regulate the electronic structure of metal atoms and P atoms at the same time, thereby greatly reducing ΔGH* and promoting hydrogen evolution reaction. The researchers [102] have successfully synthesized Fe-CoP UNSs/NF. Firstly, using the one-pot method to synthesize Fe-Co3O4 UNSs on NF (Ni Foam) substrates, and then combining Fe-Co3O4 UNSs/NFs with NaH2PO2·annealed to generate Fe-CoP UNSs/NF, as shown in Fig. 3 a. Fe-CoP UNSs has a rougher surface compared to the superficial of the NF basal, indicating that nanoparticles grow on the NF surface, as shown in Fig. 3 b. The three-dimensional framework of this Fe-CoP UNSs can not only expose more active spots, but also quicken the diffusion of electrolytes. Therefore, the prepared catalyst has good catalytic activity. The proportion of metal organic framework (MOF) can be changed by the content of Fe to further control the hydrogen evolution reaction performance. For example, a high-efficiency hydrogen evolution reaction electrocatalyst is designed and synthesized by the simple phosphating CoFe MOF [103]. After phosphating, it is still a polyhedral structure, but it exhibits a higher porosity, as shown in Fig. 3 c. In electrochemical tests, the porous Co0.68Fe0.32P polyhedron requires only 116 mV to reach 10 mA·cm−2, which has surpassed other CoFeP catalysts with Fe content [104]. Hydrogen production from seawater provides a large amount of clean energy, but it is difficult to eliminate chlorine cross-cutting and corrosion, and the battery voltage is high (> 1.7-2.4 V) and consumes a lot of electricity [105,106]. Therefore, it is very important to solve the problem of electrolysis in seawater. An innovative Fe-Co2P nanorod bundle was prepared for catalytic seawater electrolysis [107]. Due to the different amount of iron doping, there will generate CoP with different crystal phases and morphologies. It has been experimentally proved that Fe-Co2P BNRs are prepared when the molar ratio of Co: Fe is 1:0.5. It can be seen in Fig. 4 a that electronic transition in Fe-Co2P BNRs is superior to electron transfer in Mn-Co2P NRs and Co2P NRs. Fig. 4 b indicates that iron and manganese dopants reduce the |ΔGH*| of Co2P. In addition, Fe doping can accelerate the hydrogen evolution reaction kinetics of Co2P more effectively than that of Mn doping. In addition to Co-based phosphides, vanadium phosphides are also used in hydrogen evolution reaction. For example, FexVy-MOF is used as the precursor to create Fe-VyP by combining hydrothermal and Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) [108]. Compared with Fe3V1-PC/NF nanoparticles, Fe1V3-PC/NF prepared when the Fe to V ratio is low is smaller in size and denser in dispersion, which proves that latter has a strong electrochemcial active surface area (ESCA), being conducive to improve the catalytic performance, as described in Fig. 5 a. Fe1V3-PC/NF only needs 66 mV to reach 10 mA cm−2, which is much smaller than other catalysts. The incorporation of Fe into NiP can also obtain excellent hydrogen evolution reaction performance. Before the experiment, DFT simulation is carried out, and then carbon nanotubes embedded in doped Ni2P nanoparticles are prepared adopting metal organic framework (MOF) arrays as framework templates for experimental verification. DFT calculation compares the ΔGH* values of nickel, dinickel phosphide, and iron doped with dinickel phosphide [109]. Fe doping can effectively regulate the ΔGH* of Ni2P (111) and Ni (111), which significantly favors the hydrogen conversion kinetics, as shown in Fig. 5 c. The experimental results are exactly this: NF@Fe2-Ni/C hydrogen evolution reaction activity is the best of all the test agents. η10 is 33 mV. However, NF@Fe2-Ni2P/C shows smaller overpotentials than NF@Fe2-Ni/C at high current densities, showing NF@Fe2-Ni2P/C can be well used in industry, as shown in Fig. 5 d. These experiments confirm that Fe-doped TMPs have the potential to be applied in industry. The doping of Fe greatly changed the catalytic activity of TMPs, as shown in Table 4 . Obviously, Fe doping greatly improves the catalytic performance and stability of TMPs. Moreover, Fe–Co2P BNRs can have excellent catalytic performance in seawater, which provides new ideas and directions for seawater electrolysis. 4.3 Ni doping With nickel doped in TMPs, it can also change the electronic structure, and it is better in some transition metal phosphides than in other metal atoms. For example, Ni, Mn, Fe metals are incorporated into the CoP through self-template conversion (STT) strategies [28]. ZIF-67 has been used to seal the metal precursors, and then oxidized and phosphorylated them, and finally obtained the products, as shown in Fig. 6 a. In electrochemical tests, the catalytic activity of Metal-CoP/HPFs is enhanced compared to ZIF-67-derived CoP/HPFs, indicating that metal doping has a positive effect. Fig. 6 b shows that Ni-CoP/HPFs have good catalytic activity, requiring only 144 mV and 92 mV to reach 10 mA·cm−2 in acidic and basic solutions, which is far better than the doped cobalt phosphide of Mn and Fe atoms. The results show that Ni-CoP/HPFs are excellent hydrogen evolution reaction electrocatalysts, especially in basic media. It can be concluded that different metals have different degrees of influence on TMPs. There are also many researchers who determine the active sites of efficient hydrolysis catalysts at the atomic size. For example, Ni-CoP with atomic metal sites are prepared by boron-assisted method [110]. This is mainly because the existence of B induces a release-oxidation mechanism that can produce the progressive peeling off of hydroxide nanosheets, exposing more active spots, which greatly promotes hydrogen evolution performance [111]. In-plane pores on Ni-CoP nanosheets produce rich edge structures and reveal additional active sites, as shown in Fig. 6 c. Performance is as the structure shows. Ni-CoP has a passing point of 88mV at 10 mA·cm−2. DFT calculations are subsequently performed. Fig. 6 d shows that when Ni is doped, the ΔGH* of CoP is greatly reduced, and the H adsorption capacity becomes stronger. There are also electrodeposition methods to incorporate nickel into cobalt phosphide, such as the preparation of Ni-CoP films by electrodeposition [112]. The hydrogen evolution of these thin films is very effective, and the deposition time is considered as a key factor affecting the catalytic activity. At the optimal deposition time, the obtained Co−Ni−P-2 catalyst has a significant effect on HER in basic media, which needs 103 mV overpotential to reach 10 mA·cm−2, as shown in Fig. 7 a. Co−Ni−P-2 has a low Tafel slope, much smaller than when undoped, further proving that it is an excellent catalyst, as shown in Fig. 7 b. There also nickel incorporated into other metal phosphides with good results, such as Ni-FeP/TiN/CC [113]. Ni-FeP/TiN/CC is a layered structure, Fig. 7 c shows how nickel can be incorporated into this layered structure. Titanium nitride NWs are firstly produced on CC carbon fiber by solvothermal reaction and ammonia processing. Then, FeP NPs are coated on titanium nitride. Finally, plasma ions are injected to dope FeP NPs. Fig. 7 d is an HR-TEM image of nickel incorporated into a hierarchical structure, and it can be seen that the hierarchy remains unchanged after Ni ion implantation. But the nanoparticles and surface layers of titanium nitride become amorphous. Crystalline titanium nitride hastens electron transfer and the amorphous surface improves catalytic activity, so the structure shows excellent HER performance [114–116]. Lu et al. [117] also incorporates nickel into iron phosphide to modify and improve the catalytic performance. And Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy shows that the doping course don't cause abundantly variation in the crystal structure and synthetic of MIL-88A, as shown in Fig. 7 e. The passing point decreases with increasing doping, as shown in Fig. 7 f. NFP/C-3 hollow nanorods have an overpotential of only 72 mV at 10 mA·cm−2. In conclusion, Ni doping effectively improves the electrocatalytic activity, and thus enhancing the performance of HER. It can be seen from Table 5 that Ni is incorporated into TMPs, which changes its electronic structure, greatly improves its catalytic performance, and has good stability. 4.4 Co doping Co-based incorporation into TMPs is also a common method of modification. Co-doped FeP nanotubes are composited by metal-organic framework (MOF) template method [118]. CoFe MIL-88B has been composited by hydrothermal way, and then, the prepared precursor is annealed in air to obtain metal oxides (CoFeOx). Finally, phosphorylated it to obtain Co-FeP nanotubes, the specific preparation process is shown in Fig. 8 a. From TEM image of Co-FeP nanotubes shown in Fig. 8 b, the full hollow Co-FeP nanostructure can be obviously watched. The internal interval of nanotubes facilitates exposure of active spots, quality and electron transfer, and increases the approachability of electrolyte solutions. After Co doping, these advantages are further expanded. These advantages make Co-FeP nanotubes own an effective HER activity at full pH scope. Hybridization of doped TMPs with other oxides also shows excellent HER performance. For example, Co-Ni2P catalyst and its hybrid with reduced graphene oxide (rGO) are used for electrocatalysis [119]. NiCoP/rGO efficiently modulates the surface-active site, accelerates electron transfer, and improves its excellent catalytic activity. The thin nanoplates are successfully deposited on the surface of rGO, but after phosphorylation, the nanoplates are found to be morphologically deformed, as shown in Fig. 8 c. Both NiCoP and NiCoP/rGO hybrids have significant HER performance, and the cathode current density increases rapidly at higher applied voltages. Fig. 8 d shows that rGO significantly reduces the overpotential (42 mV) required to reach 10 mA·cm−2 compared to the NiCoP catalyst (59 mV). The electrochemical measurement results show that the NiCoP/rGO hybrid has excellent HER effectively and wear in the electrolyte with all pH values. The incorporation of Co into CuP also yields excellent catalytic properties, such as a simple strategy to create pigment-like Co-Cu3P structures grown on porous copper foam [120], as shown in Fig. 9 a. After phosphorylation of Co-CuO, the obtained Co-Cu3P still retains its initial form, but the surface is rough due to structural shrinkage and phase change during annealing, as shown in Fig. 9 b. This rough surface may provide more active sites, Co-Cu3P/CF exhibits excellent catalytic activity for HER. The fine performance of Co-Cu3P/CF can be attributed to its architecture, which provides abundant active spots, and the existence of Co dopants can also reasonably change its electronic characteristics, thereby producing synergistic effects. Co have also been incorporated into iron phosphide. Cho and et al. [121] have incorporated Mn, Co, Ni groups into FeP NPs and compared the changes in HER activity after doping with different elements. As shown in Fig. 9 c, Co-FeP/Ti (126 mV) has higher HER activity than that of FeP (139 mV), showing that doping Co in FeP can greatly improve the catalytic performance. Doping Ni and Mn atoms did not change the catalytic activity of FeP, because Ni-FeP and Mn-FeP require higher overpotentials than FeP/Ti to reach a current density of 100 mA·cm−2 [122]. It also shows that FeP has a stable structure regardless of the doped elements. The doping of Co greatly changed the catalytic activity of TMPs, as shown in Table 6 . It can be clearly seen that after doping, it has good catalytic activity and good stability at a wide range of pH. And NiCoP and rGO hybridization produces excellent performance. It can be seen that metal doping can be combined with the construction of composite materials to produce excellent performance, which may provide a new way for the development of TMPs. 4.5 Other metal atoms doping There are other metal atoms also doping into TMPs, such as Mo, Al, Ru, etc. For example, Mo-doped CoP synthesized by typical synthesis method, and then phosphated in tubular furnaces, as shown in Fig. 10 a [123]. The introduction of Mo atoms and Al atoms greatly prevented the aggregation of cobalt phosphide crystals and was conducive to the formation of porous CoP nanosheets. The final product has excellent electrochemical performance, CoMo(Al)-P/NF only needs 78 mV to reach 10 mA·cm−2, which is smaller than CoP/NF and CoMo-P/NF, as shown in Fig. 10 b. Although CoMo(Al)-P/NF has higher over-point than Pt/C/, the overpotential of it increases faster. This means that CoMo(Al)-P/NF electrocatalysts are more suitable than costly Pt/C electrocatalysts in industrial electrolytic water. Al atoms doped into TMPs can also play well for HER performance. Al-doped CoP is prepared with CoAl-LDH as a precursor. Al-CoP has the same nano arrays as CoAl-LDH/CC, but with a relatively rough surface, as shown in Fig. 10 c [124]. Rough surfaces can provide more active sites, increasing catalytic activity. After Al doping, the Co 2p are negatively shifted compared to in CoP [125,126]. Because there is a intense electron interaction after Al doping, which may be of great significance for regulating the electronic environment in Al-CoP to promote HER catalysis [127]. DFT calculations show that Al atoms can supply charges to Co and P atoms [128]. And the d-band center of Co atoms reduces, getting the weakened interactions between Co and H atoms and decreasing |ΔGH*| [129]. Ru doping can also well catalyze HER performance, such as the construction of a Ru-doped 3D NiCoP, as shown in Fig. 10 d [130]. The catalyst is petal-shaped and has a large electrochemical active area. DFT calculations show that Ru atoms at the Ru-NiCoP site exhibit higher density states near the Fermi level, which means that catalytic electron transfer has better conductivity, that is, Ru atoms doped at the Ni site of NiCoP can easily become the catalytic site of HER. The doping of other metal atoms also greatly changed the catalytic activity of TMPs, as shown in Table 7 . In this section, metal atom-doped bimetallic phosphides can also produce good catalytic activity and good stability. This may be able to develop in the direction of high-entropy alloys to produce more catalysts with excellent activity. Overall, metal atoms such as Fe, Ni, Co have extremely strong hydrogen evolution activity metals, and are widely used for doping transition metal phosphides. Xiong et al. [131] analyzed the effect of surface electronic structure on the catalytic performance of M-NiP through DFT calculations. ΔGH* varies linearly with the increasing charge, showing that the more electrons the dopant contributes to the surface, the stronger the adsorption energy of H* can get. Bader charge analysis exhibits that the contribution of doped different metal atoms to the electric density of Ni2P follow Co < Fe < Mn, and the charge contribution of these three metals is small [132]. When metal atoms doped with these three metals, ΔGH* is very small, similar to that of a Pt catalyst. According to the Sabatier principle, the ΔGH* of a good HER catalyst should be close to zero. Therefore, Ni2P catalysts doped with Co and Fe have good catalytic activity. Inactive atoms such as Al doped into CoP can also produce excellent catalytic performance, which may be because Al atoms replace Co atoms on the surface of CoP, greatly reducing Δ GH*. Therefore, it is very important for reducing the Gibbs free energy of materials. 5 Summary and outlook In summary, the reaction mechanism of hydrogen evolution, the preparation method of TMPs and the method of improving the performance of metal doping have been summarized in this review as shown in Scheme 1 . As we all know, the catalytic activity of pure TMPs is still not very good. Therefore, pure TMPs were doped and modified. Doping Mn has good HER catalytic activity under different pH values and Mn is abundant in the earth's crust; doping Fe and Ni atoms in TMPs can promote anion and cation exchange, thereby greatly reducing ΔGH* and promoting HER; doping of Co atoms lead to a larger specific surface area and an increase in active spots and promotes anion and cation conversion in TMPs; doping of other metal atoms also can have a similar effect. In general, metal atom doping can greatly alter the intrinsic activity of TMPs, thereby promoting HER. In addition, compared to non-metallic doping, the amount of doping is easy to control metal-doped TMPs. The difference in doping location and doping amount deeply affects the activity of the catalyst. Because the doping mechanism and reaction mechanism are not very clear. It is necessary to deeply understand the mechanism of action of metal atom doping and the true center of reaction activity, thereby promoting the industrial application of electrolyzed water. The construction of composite materials is also a commonly used modification method, and NiCoP/rGO has good catalytic activity at any pH value. There are many studies of single doping and single interface engineering, and not many studies of combining them, perhaps this is a way to build a good catalyst. Polymetallic doping, such as CoMo(Al)-P, has also been constructed, and the polymetallic synergy allows the catalyst to produce good catalytic activity. In recent years, high-entropy alloys have developed rapidly, and the construction of phosphides of high-entropy alloys may be a good way to develop. TMPs are excellent electrocatalysts. In summary, TMPs catalysts have great hydrogen evolution potential and are expected to become an alternative to precious metal catalysts. coredata.dc:description: With the soaring price of traditional energy and environmental pollution, it is important to find reliable and environmentally friendly clean energy. Transition Metal Phosphides (TMPs) have been shown to perform well compared to other non-precious metal catalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalysts. The modifications of transition metal phosphides can obtain better catalytic performance. Among that, metal doping has become a commonly used method for modifying transition metal phosphides, because it can control the amount of doping and the synthesis method is simple. Metal atom doping greatly changes the intrinsic properties of transition metal phosphides, such as adding Electrochemical Active Surface Area (ESCA), adjusting the electronic structure, etc. Transition metal phosphides can also improve catalytic activity by constructing composite materials such as NiCoP/rGO. Polymetallic doping can also improve the catalytic performance of TMPs, such as CoMo(Al)-P. Through the synergy between polymetals, the catalytic activity of the catalyst is greatly improved. Therefore, it can be developed in the direction of high-entropy alloys to produce catalysts with excellent performance. And TMPs also have good catalytic activity in seawater, such as Fe–Co2P BNRs. A series of modification methods such as metal doping will greatly tap the hydrogen evolution reaction potential of transition metal phosphides, and are expected to be applied in industry.
coredata.dc:title: A review with transition-metal phosphide electrocatalysts in hydrogen evolution reaction: Doping perspective
